title: Sawmill Watercolor Card

The sale of this card, a fund-raising project of the Latah County Historical Society, helps us to preserve and interpret the heritage of Latah County.

title: Anderson Ridge

The ridge is ahead of Main Street of old Elk River, Idaho next to 'the Big Swede.' The monument also stands as a remembrance of Gustave Malker and Per Emil Anderson.

title: Electric Generating Equipment
description: This photo shows the electric generating equipment at the Elk River plant, installed in 1910. It was the source of all electric power for the entire mill, and in the 'early days' to the town, in the evening hours, as well. The two generators and Parsons type steam turbines were built by Westinghouse. One unit, serial No. 801, was rated at 625 K.V.A the other with serial No. 766, was rated at 1000 K. V. A. Both operating at 600 volts, 3-phase, 60 cycles and 3,600 R.P.M. After Elk River was closed down the larger unit was moved andinstalled at the Potlatch mill, and was then reqired to suppply 2400 volts. Originally the each cost around $17 and $20,000.00.
publisher: University of Idaho Library Digital Initiatives, https://www.lib.uidaho.edu/digital/
source: Lee Gale Scrapbooks: Elk River, Potlatch Historical Society

title: Elk River Community Center Article
description: A newspaper article from the Clearwater Tribune in Orofino, Idaho about the $200,000 Community Center dedicated to Elk River. The article mentions appearances by Governor John Evans, the Andrew Bloom pioneering family, Mayor Everett Lovell, the governor sponsor and Clearwater County Commissioner candidate Bill Crutcher, Miss Elk River Rita Coomer, Mayor Tracy Planagan, and others. The luncheon was followed by a question and answer period with the students from a participating school. Several awards and certificates were presented at the time.

title: Plant, Shops, and other Buildings
description: The plants construction progress about a month before it cut the first lumber, Sept. 11th 1906. To the right of the sawmill is the W.I.&M. round house, machine shop and car repair shop. Behind that is the planer building (long white roof) and the planer power house still under construction. In the right foreground is the Potlatch Mercantile building with the outside walls barely up. In the foreground is the old ranch house, barn and outbuildings that were there when Deary purchased the land in June 1905. Note the outhouse, lower right.

title: Max Williamson
description: A photograph of Max Williamson, assistant sales manager for the Potlatch Lumber Company. He promoted physical fitness and recreational development for the employees of Potlatch. They hired physical education directors as staff and created the Potlatch Amateur Athletic Club that had 400 members.
